subject: Re: [junit] Re: Doubt!
msgSnippet: ... I understand the documentation is old. That s why Mike Clark and I each wrote well-known, widely-read tutorials on JUnit. They just aren t in the JUnit
messageBody:
Shinobu Kawai wrote:

>
> Hi all, (mostly Kent and Erich ;-)
>
> > I do not know whether this is a big problem, but /do not/ override
> > runTest().
> Maybe the problem is in the JUnit Cookbook.
> http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookbook/cookbook.htm
>
> Here is an excerpt:
> 1. Create an instance of TestCase:
> 2. Create a constructor which accepts a String as a parameter and passes
> it to the superclass.
> 3. Override the method runTest()
> 4. When you want to check a value, call assertTrue() and pass a boolean
> that is true if the test succeeds
>
> I'm not sure, but this is probably for an older version of JUnit. When I
> make tests, I don't do #2 and #3.

I understand the documentation is old. That's why Mike Clark and I each
wrote well-known, widely-read tutorials on JUnit. They just aren't in
the JUnit distribution.

Do note that the Cookbook (or Test Infected, I can't remember which)
/does/ go on to say, "Starting with JUnit 2.0, there's an easier way..."
and describes the current way of writing tests as test*() methods.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
